Title: Evil Dead: Hail to the King
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 40, 'text': 'While there are a few interesting spots and plot points, Evil Dead the game has managed to turn one of the most original and entertaining of all B-horror-film franchises into nothing more than a boring, uninspired, and pedestrian attempt to cash in on a license. '}, {'score': 66, 'text': "If you're bored, though, at least go out and rent Evil Dead: Hail To The King. Otherwise, there's really no need for you to return to the cabin in the woods."}, {'score': 60, 'text': "I really wanted to recommend this game, despite it's problems with controls and graphics I would still have recommended it to fans of the genre and 'Evil Dead' movies, however because of the length all I can say is rent it out some time."}, {'score': 70, 'text': 'A bitter pill to swallow. Still, you could waste an afternoon or two on this and still find yourself fairly amazed with some of the puzzle elements, the hunt for horror exploration aspect, and all the chainsaw-ripping, zombie-blasting gore. '}, {'score': 60, 'text': "Hit-or-miss, mushy controls mean you're dead more often than not even though combat with Deadites is a simple button-smashing slugfest. "}]
User Reviews Data: [{'score': 7, 'text': 'First game i owned and played to death on DC never understood the hate for it.'}]

Title: Legends of Pegasus
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 48, 'text': 'Sadly, technical problems make this game nearly unplayable- it?€?s like Legends of Pegasus launched half-finished. Somewhere, deep inside, there?€?s a great game, with an interesting space-opera story, presented like a graphic-novel  but in the end, the worst alien menace in Legends of Pegasus is not the race of X?€?or or Arthrox but the bugs. And not like the bugs in Starship Troopers [January 2013]'}, {'score': 30, 'text': 'Legends of Pegasus game is perfect example of how to turn ambitious projects into something you do want to forget as fast as possible. [Oct 2012]'}, {'score': 30, 'text': 'An impenetrable mess with almost nothing to recommend it. Cast this one into the void. [Oct 2012, p.73]'}]
User Reviews Data: [{'score': None, 'text': 'I was excited to see a real time space strategy with lots of achievement on steam and pre-ordered the game for the price of an AAA title. Never again. The game was practically unplayable and buggy; the first patches did nothing valuable. Then the developer filed for bankruptcy with no hope from the community side to make this game ever playable. Unfortunately, there was no refund available from my country. The sad thing is that the game was still available for purchase for months after.'}, {'score': None, 'text': "I'm unsure what happened with LoP. While in development, the game seemed to have decent support. Then, suddenly, Summer of 2012,  It was released in a less-than-playable state with non-existent support. Complaints from people who had paid for the game in good faith were everywhere. Players were discussing how to approach getting their money refunded. In October of 2012 the developers filed for Bankruptcy. I haven't seen a really decent explanation of why LoP was released before it was ready although many claim that's how Kalypso does business. Others say publishers are pushing developers into premature release of their games. Some sites were still taking orders for LoP at the time that Novacore announced its insolvency which is, IMHO, inexcusable. The only reason why some people were spared is bc players posted warnings not to buy the game.   More than a few people reported that they were denied refunds due to game time logged even though they were not able to actually play the game. This calls into question the ethics of charging players for games not yet published. Aren't beta players really assisting developers in identifying problems needing to be solved? Shouldn't there be some kind of reward offered to the people who play pre-release games? How fair is it to charge people who participate in beta testing the full price for the game when they are the ones assuming the risk that the game might flop?"}, {'score': None, 'text': 'DO NOT BUY THIS!!! This game is unfinished, and unplayable! A travesty to the genre!'}]

Title: Homeworld
Publisher: Sierra Entertainment, Frogster Interactive, Sold Out Software
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 100, 'text': "Simply one of those titles that makes you say 'Wow.' You'll have to pick your jaw up off the floor when you experience it for the first time. It is a rare gem; an awesome feat of programming, graphical design, and sound production, all wrapped around superb gameplay. It deserves the highest praise."}, {'score': 90, 'text': 'With its stunning 3D engine, uniquely challenging gameplay in both single- and multiplayer modes, great audio, and terrific story, Homeworld is both an excellent game and one that may well reshape the entire real-time strategy genre.'}, {'score': 91, 'text': 'Not only has control of this environment been handled well, but the smoothness of overall presentation and gameplay seem to reflect an excellence from RTS titles that we should all be looking forward to in the future.'}]
User Reviews Data: [{'score': 10, 'text': 'Jedna z najlepszych strategi czasu rzeczywistego jak kiedykolwiek zrobiono. Arcydzieo gatunku.'}, {'score': 9, 'text': "At the time of writing its been roughly 25 years since the original homeworld came out. Its graphics are dated, its controls are clunky, its audio is crunchy. Even with those up front it is still the grandaddy of all space-based RTS games with an appreciable depth to it. A depth that was lost when HW1 was 'Remastered' in homeworld 2's engine.\n\nThe classic version of HW1 gearbox packages with the remastered collection is non-functional on modern machines. A different version will need to be acquired elsewhere."}, {'score': 10, 'text': 'The most special RTS game in the history of game. Real Revolution RTS better than Starcraft'}]

Title: Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 100, 'text': 'Simply put, Call of Duty 4 does everything right and nearly nothing wrong. But where it elevates itself above even the best 360 shooters is how all of the good stuff is ludicrously good. The campaign never lets up, while multiplayer is a triple-A affair in itself.  [Dec 2007, p.36]'}, {'score': 90, 'text': "COD4 is cutting-edge entertainment, but the downside to this dense and gripping delivery is that it's over far too quickly: five to six hours on Normal difficulty...COD4 is short but immensely satisfying and we can't wait for a post-modern revival. [Dec 2007, p.73]"}, {'score': 94, 'text': "Though the single-player lacks length, the multiplayer should keep you invested in COD4 for the long winter. This is a truly fantastic multiplayer offering that's as deep as any other online game available."}]
User Reviews Data: [{'score': 9, 'text': 'I may be viewing this through the lens of rose-tinted nostalgia glasses, but I think this was one of the most incredible games of the mid-2000s, and set the precedent for the vast majority of first-person shooters since. Incredible for the time, but I am unsure if it would be enjoyable almost twenty years later.'}, {'score': 10, 'text': 'Call of Duty 4 Modern Warfare is one of those games that just feels timeless. It campaign is still awesome to play through and one of the repayable games too. Its multiplayer also shines too, with it overall being a fun experience. Title: Blue Prince
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 100, 'text': 'Blue Prince blends puzzles and roguelike exploration into something refreshingly original, clever, calm, and unlike anything else you?€?ve played.'}, {'score': 90, 'text': 'Blue Prince is a game that you can easily get yourself engrossed with. What appeared to be a simple game turned out to be one full of surprises around the corner, making it a must-play game for puzzle and roguelike fans alike.'}, {'score': -1, 'text': 'Blue Prince is one of those games that demonstrates a depth and excellence that we rarely see in the world of video games. [Recommended]\r\n'}]
User Reviews Data: [{'score': 8, 'text': 'A really original game. A good mix of roguelike and puzzles, with an excellent artistic direction. Would love to see more from the studio in the future.'}, {'score': 7, 'text': 'Amazing experience the first few days I played it but then it becomes frustrating due to the RNG of the rogue like system and it does feel very incomplete towards the end stuff'}, {'score': 8, 'text': 'Blue Prince is a mesmerizing blend of mystery and elegance. Its shifting manor, rich with surreal architecture and clever spatial puzzles, creates a captivating sense of discovery. The atmosphere is moody and dreamlike, supported by subtle audio design that enhances every room. With its inventive progression and constantly unfolding secrets, Blue Prince delivers a uniquely haunting and intelligent puzzle experience. I would only deduce some points cause the Roguelike aspect of it seems a bit off, not per se, but it needs more equalization.'}]

Title: Batman: Arkham Asylum
Publisher: Eidos Interactive, Square Enix, Bandai Namco Games
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 96, 'text': "Arkham Asylum is a game with the power to utterly captivate you and can stand proudly alongside modern classics such as 'Resident Evil 4', 'Gears of War,' and 'BioShock'...Simply put, Batman: Arkham Asylum is a masterpiece. [Sept 2009, p.66]"}, {'score': 95, 'text': "Batman: Arkham Asylum is this year's 'BioShock,' not just from the connection established with the world, but from its ability to innovate where new ideas are needed, and moreover, deliver an adventure unlike any other. [Sept 2009, p.82]"}, {'score': 95, 'text': "A massively impressive licensed game. Without a license holding it all together Arkham Asylum would have been a stunning game with striking features. That it's all wrapped up in Batman's world makes the experience so much more appealing, and it works both as an extension of lore for Batman enthusiasts and an entry point for those less familiar with the DC universe. [Oct 2009, p.84]"}]

Az biraz izlemitim arkada??mdan. ??zlerken minik tatl?? bir macera oyunu gibi duruyordu ama y??kledikten sonra abart??lan??n hi?? de az olduunu d????nm??yorum. Oyun baya baya hardcore zorlukta bir souls oyunu. T??r??n?? normalde alayarak oynasamda beni oyundan s??kmad??. Bir s??re sonra sinirlenip 1-2 bossun nas??l kesileceine bakmam d????nda a??r?? zor ama imkans??z seviyesinde deildi. Oyunun genel hatlar??ndan bahsetmemiz gerekirse oyun 'Gidem bosslara 1 saat vuram can?? d??s??n' 'Hata yapt??m pat ??l' tarz?? bir souls deil. Her bossun zay??fl??klar?? var ve oraya vurduun gibi ??l??yor. Oyunda zaten minyon d??man yok. Boss'u kes dierine git boss'u kes dierine git eklinde. Mekanik desen zaten koma , y??r??me , ok atma , oku ??ekme ve roll'dan ileriye gitmiyor her ey senin kontrol??nde. Her ??ld????nde git batan boss'a 15 sn y??r?? k??sm?? d???? sorunu yok. Hikayesi de yok zaten. Ama ??ok iyi. M??zikleri ise beni gaza getirdi baya kaliteli. Yapanlar kimse a??r?? iyi i ????karm??.Burdan ??neren arkada??ma teekk??r edip bende size ??neriyorum. Puan?? Metacritic'te falan az olsa da benim i??in baya y??ksek "}, {'score': 8, 'text': "God creates the TitansGod creates manThe Titans destroy GodMan creates the bow and arrowThe Titans destroy manThe chosen one will destroy the Titans (or the joystick)I promised myself that I would recover this title at any cost. The first work from the studio that created the jewel that is Death's Door absolutely had to be played. I wanted to understand how a game like the one released in 2021 was born and to do this the best way is to find out where they started. What can I say with a start like this you can only go high!The Manchester studio began its adventure in the infinite world of video games in 2015, basing its creation on minimalist Pixel Art graphics, on an inspired and varied setting and building everything around a high and ruthless difficulty, with shades of frustration in the air.With a top-down view, a barely mentioned story and a basic tutorial, the player is introduced to the game with a single purpose: to kill the 'Titans'. Majestic, agile and ruthless creatures that populate mini areas scattered here and there around the world.There are no 'simple' enemies, only checkpoints in strategic positions, in order to make recovery after game over simple and many bosses to face.Once you enter the arena the battle begins and there are only two ways to get out: alive, hitting the monster's weak point, or dead, the more probable **** hit is enough to trigger the game over but the same goes for the opponent we will face, with the only obligation that we should hit him in his 'hidden' weak point with the only arrow present in our hero's quiver. That's right, just an arrow which, however, can be thrown and retrieved infinitely either by walking on it or by recalling it with telekinetic powers, taking into account that without a weapon we are effectively harmless and at the mercy of the monster. In a nutshell, the clash with a new creature is divided into two phases: the first of gathering information and modus operandi of the giant in question and the second of implementing the attack plan, carefully designed in one's head, to get the upper hand . Many attempts separate the player from victory, especially with the last ruthless giants, but the goal to be achieved is never too far away, and the satisfaction of seeing the David within us defeat the Goliath of the moment, will manage to tear more than a smile from lips of those who will be able to seize the best moment to strike.David Fenn's first musical works already show the talent and skill of the English singer-songwriter which years later will lead him to create one of my favorite soundtracks, that of Death's door!The staging in this title is obviously still immature, a sort of embryonic version of what will later become a very respectable soundtrack in the subsequent work. But despite this, he does his accompanying work damn well and more than one track will have the ability to carve out a space in the hearts of fans. This is for two reasons: one unconscious, as by repeating a clash infinite times and then listening to the notes continuously the player will end up loving (or hating) the tracks and the other because some music will have the ability to give us a boost in times of need to win the battle.Acid Nerve's inspiration from Fumito Ueda's game Shadow of the Colossus released 10 years earlier is great; a character in a lonely world who must defeat creatures who are even difficult to approach. Of course, the differences on a technical, graphic, setting and duration level bring the two titles to different levels of the global video game scale. The work of Team Ico has entered history and the hearts of fans, something that the first work of the English team will never be able to do. Despite this, I consider the Indie 'game' an experience, which however short, deserves to be lived. Of course it is not a title for those who get discouraged at the first difficulty but only for those, like me, who get excited in the most challenging moments. Let's be clear, nothing is impossible, we just need to get carried away and savor with calm, perseverance and attentive eyes the right moment to launch the arrow into the Titan's 'Achilles' heel'."}]

Title: Moonlighter
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 80, 'text': "Like all the finest indie titles, Moonlighter has such a simple premise but is done so masterfully it becomes fantastically addictive - from the basic combat, to the Resident Evil style bag management, to upgrading the shop, to selling the goods; every aspect feels great. Combine this with the charming old-school art and you have got a clear winner on your hands. The only real negative is how short the game is and how the story feels a little lightweight. Moonlighter also feels like it would be even better on Switch, so keep an eye out for Cubed3's review of that version soon!"}, {'score': 85, 'text': "Though it comes with some bugs, ample load times when entering or leaving a dungeon, and an English localization that shows some evidence of the developer's Spanish roots, Moonlighter presents well. While some may shy away from the repetitive formula, I am certain fans of the roguelike genre will find a lot to play with in Moonlighter. That being said, the scant story is not so demanding that players need commit fully to it in one continuous playthrough. Thus, Digital Sun has developed Moonlighter into something that feels as timeless as its role models and will welcome back players delve after delve. "}, {'score': 90, 'text': 'Moonlighter is an exciting action adventure-shop simulator game that shouldn?€?t be skipped. If you have any interest in running a shop and dungeon diving, then this game is for you.'}]

Title: Freedom: First Resistance
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 20, 'text': "Your best bet? Leave this game at the store and pick up a VHS copy of the 'V' miniseries if you really need a cheesy alien invasion fix."}, {'score': 38, 'text': "For a game that puts so much emphasis on its pedigree as a set of novels, there's precious little storytelling in F:FR. Title: MindsEye
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': -1, 'text': 'MindsEye isn?€?t ruined by bugs, but its outdated ideas and poor gameplay hold it back. At least its cinematics provide an interesting visual glimpse. [No Recommended]'}, {'score': 30, 'text': "Its world feels considered. There are decent performances from its cast among the graphical artefacts, and zippy pacing that respects your time and conjures a sense of playing the Schwarzenegger role that never was. But it's been released in a technical state that makes it impossible to enjoy its ideas, with core components of its action left underdeveloped. For the player, that's frustrating. For those who made it, surely, it's heartbreaking. [Issue413, p.112]"}, {'score': 40, 'text': 'MindsEye offers an original narrative and a powerful level creator tool within a dystopian open world, but it suffers from repetitive, uninspired gameplay and poor technical performance, especially on mid-range PCs and Steam Deck. Despite well-crafted cutscenes and a promising concept, the lack of polish, outdated design choices, and insufficient support for the creation system greatly limit its appeal.'}]
User Reviews Data: [{'score': 6, 'text': 'MindsEye almost has it all: big action set-pieces, attacking drones, car chases, drama, and a huge amount of Arcadia content. It?€?s the kind of game you can sink hours into, go to sleep, and jump straight back into the next day. The problem is the bugs and glitches ?€? they break immersion and drag the experience down. I genuinely like this game and the potential is huge, but in its current state, it doesn?€?t quite add up. I?€?m sticking with a 6/10 for now, and I?€?ll revisit and adjust my review if future updates clean things up.'}, {'score': 2, 'text': 'What initially seemed like an exciting new game from a promising developer, led by former GTA producer Leslie Benzies, quickly fell short of expectations. Swarming with bugs, inconsistent frame rates, and generic gameplay, this title fails to reach the ambitious heights it aimed for. You?€?ll likely find yourself wishing you had chosen something else to play.'}, {'score': 4, 'text': "I waited for the update 5 to play the game, and it runs bad, is like doesn't matter it you set everything to low and put some upscaling , the game still has serious performance issues even in closed spaces.\nI don't think the game itself is as bad as some people says, the story is somewhat decent at least, but you can see that they rushed everything and very often you get bits of the story while you are in a car chase or during gun combat, and you can't pay attention to that. The cutscenes are good, the ending is open and was rushed.\nI don't know if the studio has the  and the people to get this game fixed, but unless they make an extreme modification the game will still ****."}]

Title: Montague's Mount

I reccommend only if you have the patience to wrangle with its confusing and poorly-designed layout, otherwise don't bother."}, {'score': 10, 'text': "I'm into psychological games, pretty hardcore, Montague's Mount is one of those psychological games I love. Throughout the game on and off it gave me a feeling of being watched.
I did get lost a few times in the game, but once you figure it out, the game isn't that bad.
I personally didn't have any issues with my game crashing or losing saves, no bugs. The game gave me no problems what so ever.
Not sure how much this game changed with the update, or how much help was added, even before the update I did have fun with this game. Title: Elden Ring: Shadow of the Erdtree
Critic Reviews Data:
[{'score': 80, 'text': 'Not just the wide range of new weapons and magic, but also challenging yet well-designed boss battles make Elden Ring: Shadow of the Erdtree an experience well worth your time. However, the lack in variety of new regular enemies and an open world that feels too big for its own good make this DLC feel less polished than the original game.'}, {'score': 90, 'text': 'FromSoftware continues to rule the genre
it invented. If you didn?€?t care for Elden Ring,
run away screaming. Otherwise, come on in
and scream with frustration. [Issue43, p.92]'}, {'score': 90, 'text': 'Expanding on Elden Ring?€?s already impeccable legacy in meaningful and spectacular ways, Shadow of the Erdtree is another triumph from FromSoftware. Some of the series?€? best boss battles, visually stunning vistas and a leaner yet equally deep narrative lend this expansion the right to be considered one of the best pieces of DLC money can buy.'}]
User Reviews Data:
[{'score': 9, 'text': 'While the game offers plenty of enjoyable elementsa map comparable in size to the main installment, challenging yet captivating bosses, a more accessible storyline than its predecessors, and various engaging gimmicksthe overall density feels lacking. The open fields seem to serve merely as passageways for navigation rather than meaningful exploration, which is somewhat disappointing.'}, {'score': 10, 'text': 'Fromsoft outdid itself this time. Elden Ring is the height of gaming! Excellent title!'}, {'score': 10, 'text': "Even better than OG game. 

This is one of the kind. When I think of this DLC I think of it as one of the best DLCs of all time.

This DLC is like a sequel - with everything! Its WAST gorgeous map with highly enjoyable exploration.  There are several 'bioms' with different theme and feeling to it. Music and ambience of the places is magical. Bosses and chunkier enemies are fun. There are several NPCs with questlines which are comparably good with the main game. The price could feel a bit much for a DLC, but I sunk 80hours to my first playthrough and I would say that games for that price tag giving you usually less. And you couldn t say this DLC is just some appendix, it is full-fledged story expansion.

My only gripe for console players is that you need to have save saved or be good at speedrunning for reaching the point when you can enter the DLC... I would be glad that FromSoft be in the future more generous with choices for subsequent playthroughs like (yes, you can rant how ridiculous was the state of the game after launch, but they do quite a job on it and the game is quite a looker and runs smoothly) Lord of the Fallen or Lies of P (in the terms of mix and match the equipment possibilities) - you could unlock something during first plathrough and have it ticked somewhere if you choose to for next playthrough. These games are massive and I understand there is a picky community and splendid no-hit-runners and all, but that is not all. Some quality of life things would not dismantle the difficulty or anything, just to have more fun with more weapons and theirs unique move sets. I enjoyed DLC more because i had all smithing stones and I was not bothered to farm somthing, at last! The runes I acquired during playthrough went straight to the smithing stones and I could use any weapon right away. I would really love the idea for the future when you are finding the materials for the 'tree of weapons' not for individual weapons - especially when the game is that big as Elden ring or this DLC and you have TONS of nice looking weapons which you will never use because you would just farm something for it(even if you are ok with just lvl24/lvl9 weapon)."}]

Title: Orion: Dino Horde
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 35, 'text': "It may be fun if we play with friends for a few hours but it may be not. There are many games fighting in the FPS genre, and it's very hard to find something worth highlighting in this one."}, {'score': 45, 'text': "While Orion: Dino Horde has potential, it will certainly fall short of even modest expectations. If it weren't for there already being quite the track record of bad Jurassic games, I'd suggest that fighting dinosaurs has never been so dull. A shame, since it's evident that the developers put a lot of time into it... it's just too bad they didn't focus on making it fun. "}, {'score': 30, 'text': "Perhaps I shouldn?€?t have been surprised that ORION: Dino Horde was such a disappointment. The gaming industry has been rife with rumors about scurrilous behaviour concerning a very similar title, Dino Beatdown. ORION: Dino Horde's rough edges suggest that it has been quickly brought to market and cynically shoveled out to gamers in the vain hope that its over the top premise will bring in a few bucks."}]
User Reviews Data:
[{'score': 5, 'text': "It's no Turok.
I'mma admit right off the bat that I actually had fun playing this. Perhaps more than I should have. But I get told that a lot. Apparently you're only meant to have a 'little bit of fun' over-waxing the floor at a shopping centre. Normal people falling is fun, but when the kid on crutches does the exact same thing - no more fun. I learn things everyday.
For example, today when I was looking for this game on Metacritic I learned that it's had several name changes for no good reason. I looked for the game I played titled ORION: Prelude, but couldn't find it until I realised it used to be called ORION: Dino Horde. And that in itself was a rebrand from ORION: Dino Beatdown. You know that guy in 'The Good Place' that went to hell for being too indecisive? Well, Spiral Game Studios is where he got his training. I can only imagine what ORION: New Circle of Hell they're in for when they die.
So this game released to raving negative reviews. It was more broken than that crutches kid after having a personal introduction to that floor. And while several bugs remain to this day, for the most part this game has since been made a stable experience. Just don't play the Summit map. You shouldn't be playing that anyway. Without the bugs that's still just the worst map. You could say that Summit really peaked in annoying game design.
i'll see myself out now...
But yeah, other than Summit turning the skybox and half the models completely black, meaning good luck seeing all those pterodactyls soaring around in the endless void, the game is truly playable. Now I don't wanna excuse a dev team for releasing and selling a broken product only to fix it later because, as we now know, this would become an anti-consumer standard practice in the industry. However, I'll let this slide as it was their first game and they seemed to improve this attitude for their next release before disappearing forever. Yea, it's just hard to be mad at something that doesn't exist. Although my girlfriend would disagree with that statement after I cheated on her with my co-worker. I'm an internet funny man. I don't have a co-worker. But hey, the realm of physicality won't stop me from having an imaginary ORION: Post-Lube Inspection. Apparently.
Anyway, video game. I only played the survival mode during my time with this game. There are less-than-a-few players still hopping around these servers. That's a real shame, because those strange times when another person from somewhere in the world did decide to load up this strange game 9 years after release and found my lobby were the best times. There are bots that try to help if no one else joins your game. I specifically say 'try to help' because their only use was as ORION: Dino Bait. They won't repair the generator you're defending, they won't use anything other than the basic rifle, and only rarely will they feel the need to pick you up after you've been downed. No, mostly their job description suggests they should run around erratically like a headless chicken until dinos show up and then they plant their feet firmly and take on the horde with their face. They kill a good deal of them before they die though. That's sweet of them.
This makes a great deal of otherwise optional things an absolute necessity because you are now fulfilling the roles of 5 team members, regardless of which class you pick. Trying to repair the generator will set all the big boss dinos on you immediately, like they're offended by the sounds engineers make. So you won't have a chance to get it back up before the knockback sends you to another map. Unless it's the T-Rex which either chomps you, or if you have the no-chomp upgrade, simply lodges you inside its model where you cannot leave as it slowly nibbles on the salty snack that was your face.
So with all these problems, why did I say I had fun? 2 reasons mostly.
Reason number A: I love most of the environments. It's not the most graphically appealing game, or the one with the most detailed worlds. Yet, most of the maps really do look pretty. I'm a **** for open spaces and over-saturated colours in everything, and this game REALLY scratches that itch. I also love the look of the jagged and interestingly structured mountains.
Reason number II: Play the assault class and buy the TREK bow. I had so much dumb fun jetpacking around popping off arrows at dinos and watching them fall like Hawkeye in Avengers, except I actually achieve something.  Then there's the alternative arrows. If you do manage to get a player in your game do a favour for me, would ya? When they're in a vehicle and least expect it, fly to the top of a mountain a knock out their car with an EMP arrow. The arrows are too small to see and you are way out of sight so they'll never know what happened. And that makes me happy.
So I did have a lot of dumb fun playing this game. I can't recommend it as a brilliant product, but I can tell you to just do it anyway
Just play ORION: Subtitle Pending"}, {'score': 10, 'text': ' .   , , ,  .  .'}, {'score': 6, 'text': "TL;DR at the bottom for those with little time to spare :)

Objectively speaking, this game is meh, it's a bit of dumb fun with friends that can keep you occupied for maybe 1-2 hours. However, given it's price and how easy it is to play. It's worth a couple of bucks, especially if it's on sale. Make no mistake, this game is not amazing, it's not good. It's passable, but it's so much fun!

However it's not fully fleshed out and a little repetitive, but to it's credit, it was once a lot worse and the developers did listen to community feedback....until they made their next game.

TL;DR
Time waster
Fun
Cheap
Not fully fleshed out
Repetitive
Developers listened to feedback, they have the potential to do it again!

Final Score: 6/10"}]

Title: Raven Squad: Operation Hidden Dagger
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 30, 'text': 'Raven Squad is 90 percent first-person shooter, 10 percent strategy game, and 100 percent bad.'}, {'score': 20, 'text': 'Don?€?t play this game. Title: Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': -1, 'text': 'People expect their sequels to be bigger, better, and more complex than what has come before, while also demanding they stay true to what they know and love. Metal Gear Solid V is one of those rare occasions where a game threads the needle between those two somewhat contradictory expectations, to great effect.'}, {'score': -1, 'text': 'At more than 60 hours into the game, pushing forward toward 70, it feels like there?€?s still a lot of The Phantom Pain left on the table. For every new detail I discoverlike taking that masterpiece of stealth tech, the man-sized cardboard box, and slapping a pin-up poster on it, thus ruining its stealthinessit seems like there are five more details waiting just beyond my reach.'}, {'score': 90, 'text': "If this is where Kojima does finally leave the series he created, it will be a bittersweet send-off, both for Big Boss and one of gaming's most intriguing auteurs."}]
User Reviews Data: [{'score': 9, 'text': 'i came to this game thinking i wouldnt like it that much. but the game surprised me so much. the gameplay of the game is something amazing even for today, almost no game has the quality and freedom of its gameplay. the soundtrack is also amazing. the only flaw that really made me take a point, is the plot twist in the true ending. in my mind i just dont take the plot twist as canon'}, {'score': 8, 'text': "Metal Gear Solid 5 is one of the best games you'll ever be disappointed by.  Its gameplay is undeniably exceptional -- expertly melding Metal Gear's traditional stealth gameplay with a more 'do-it-your-own-way' open-world sandbox structure -- and unlike previous games in the series, the core of MGS5 is its gameplay over story and cutscenes.  However, the story that is here is a mess -- notoriously unfinished.  Furthermore, MGS5 features a twist so ridiculously dumb and pointless that it would make M. Night Shyamalan blush."}, {'score': 9, 'text': "It's so good an it could have been the best stealth game ever... It's impressive that in 10 yearst there hasn't been anything better in this genre. The gameplay loop of MGSV is so fun and addictive. The freedom of approach is great! Overall it's also polished and there were zero bugs. Storywise also interesting but the end was mid. There's a huge arsenal of weapons and tools to develop. The only negatives are that there were a few of the worst designed and annoying missions/checkpoints I've ever seen in my life and a third of the game are recycled missions. It was almost perfect but still better than a lot of games coming out nowadays."}]

"}, {'score': 90, 'text': 'Arkham City handles its side-stories gloriously. User Reviews Data: [{'score': 9, 'text': 'Graphics ?€? 9/10Arkham City builds on its predecessor with an even more striking visual presentation. The UI remains clean, readable, and stylistically consistent, making health, XP, and gadget management **** environment is a massive highlightthe open city feels alive, grimy, and deeply immersive, filled with small details that reward exploration and reinforce the world?€?s oppressive atmosphere.Character models are excellent across the board. Joker, Two-Face, and Bane look iconic and refined, capturing the perfect blend of comic-book exaggeration and gritty realism.Animation quality is top-tier in combat and traversalsmooth, fluid, and empowering, making every punch, glide, and takedown feel like an authentic Batman moment. The only weak point lies in dialogue animations, where character movements don?€?t always match the tone of their speech.Still, visually, Arkham City shines.Audio ?€? 8/10The music supports the atmosphere well, even if few tracks stand out as truly memorable.Sound effects are crisp and satisfyingcombat hits sound impactful, and gadget use feels appropriately mechanical and weighty.Voice acting remains a major strength of the series. Batman and Joker?€?s performances are excellent, adding emotional weight and personality to every scene.Gameplay ?€? 8/10Controls can feel a bit clunky at times, which is understandable given the expanded set of gadgets and traversal options.Combat remains the game?€?s most creative and refined system, with smooth chaining, expressive combos, and satisfying takedowns that make every encounter **** game is simply fun to play, especially with the shift to an open city. The added sidequests and activities make the world feel busy, dangerous, and alive.Gadgets enhance both combat and puzzle-solving, offering a strong sense of progression as new tools unlock and expand Batman?€?s capabilities.Story ?€? 9/10Arkham City delivers a compelling narrative supported by strong dialogue and excellent line delivery from the voice cast.Environmental storytelling, however, is where the game truly excels. Posters, props, hidden details, and environmental clues work together to paint a rich picture of Gotham?€?s darkest district, adding depth without overwhelming the player.Overall Arkham City takes everything great about Arkham Asylum and expands it into a richer, more complex world. With superb visuals, powerful voice acting, refined combat, and an atmospheric open city, it remains one of the best superhero games ever made. Minor control issues and weak dialogue animations hold it back slightly, but not enough to dull its impact.Final Score: 9/10'}, {'score': 9, 'text': 'I first experienced the Arkham series with this never played the Arkham series before this after playing this i was hooked on the fishing reel I got the xb1 version now on digital great game'}, {'score': 9, 'text': 'lo recomiendo para cualquier fan de batman  y mas si lo compras en el pack de 3 juegos'}]

Title: UFO 50
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 100, 'text': "UFO 50 may be inspired by an era that's several generations ago, but an incredible amount of imagination and work went into making this collection of games more than just about evoking nostalgia. The collection also manages to feel fresh and innovative, delivering thrills and the feeling of discovery at nearly every turn. It's unlike anything I've played, and represents a passion and love for the medium in such a special way."}, {'score': 80, 'text': 'Judging UFO 50 is a challenge, even just for the sheer amount of content it contains, with an incredible array of ideas, mechanics, and concepts that you?€?ll find within this alternate universe. Through its video games, UFO 50 narrates a historical moment, an era that never actually existed but lives within our memories, sensations, and the emotions we felt as children, back when this world was still unexplored. At the same time, it requires a certain devotion, a passion for a very specific kind of retro gaming and a lot of patience to explore.'}, {'score': 80, 'text': 'UFO 50 is like stumbling across a time capsule and discovering a wealth of lost knowledge inside. And yet, it?€?s entirely a singular work of fiction. That by itself is deeply fascinating and makes this thing worth playing. Even if you pass over most of the games and only find a few that stick with you from a fun perspective, the depth on a conceptual level is absurd and gratifying to simply think about. We?€?re living at a time in which older games are vanishing from both physical reality and our sort of collective cultural well at an increasing rate, when remakes are seen as replacements for original work and curiosity to seek out history is dwindling unless there?€?s a purchasable remaster. UFO 50 is fun to play and take at face value, but it also highlights how age really isn?€?t a detriment to having a great time and engaging with games.'}]
User Reviews Data:
[{'score': 10, 'text': 'It?€?s 50 games how are you not playing it or are on the fence about it stop reading reviews play it'}, {'score': 4, 'text': "I'm genuinely shocked at how overhyped this title is... Almost every game out of the 50 is frustrating, irritating, and simply bad for me. It's a waste of time and money. 

I highly recommend quickly playing through some games within the first 2 hours so you can get a refund if you don?€?t enjoy it like I didn?€?t.I was really shocked by how horrible my experience was... I had heard so many positive reviews on YouTube, and I?€?ve never been so let down by my expectations. 

This title is so overhyped, and it?€?s just sad. The controls in every game are clunky, imprecise, and irritating. Enemy AI is way too high, making the games very hard and almost impossible to feel anything besides frustration and anger. There are some good ideas, but every one of them is ruined by shallow gameplay and pointless difficulty.

If you really want to experience some nostalgia, you?€?re better off playing NES, GBC, or GBA games"}, {'score': 8, 'text': 'I?€?d give it a 7.5 if possible. 

UFO 50 is so cool, but a little bit too artsy for its own good. I have such little desire to dive any deeper than surface level into either the games or the overarching story that I?€?m left without enough patience to withstand the slow and frustrating stuff in the package. As a 2000?€?s kid, the nostalgic angle of this is how games used to be does nothing for me. That said, the good stuff is so good, that I don?€?t really care if some of the games aren?€?t. I?€?d pay the price of admission JUST for Bushido Ball. Or Party House. Or Rail Hiest. Or Velgress. These are just plain fun, if not a little simple, games that are full of indie charm. If you?€?re under 30 years old, it?€?s a pretty big toss up if you?€?ll enjoy this, I think. But if you have nostalgia or major appreciation for the 8 and 16 bit eras, this is the game for you.'}]

Title: A Vampyre Story
Publisher: Crimson Cow, GamersGate, DreamCatcher Interactive, Strategy First, Ascaron Entertainment
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 60, 'text': "If in search for the next best thing in adventures, A Vampyre Story isn't it. While it has some issues, and an obvious lack of polish at places, it definitely has its moments, and some of these moments are awesome. It's not perfect, but genre fans will enjoy the three or so evenings they'll spend on it, with its humour, likable protagonist, and beautiful vistas being the best things on offer and the fact that this is basically a Part One of a Part Two that never came (and probably never will) ruining the experience."}, {'score': 83, 'text': 'A Vampyre Story is a humorous adventure, which provides many difficult mysteries and a lot of fun. The voice of the character Mona is very annoying in the German version, so install the English one.'}, {'score': 80, 'text': 'A Vampyre Story is clearly a labour of love, although whether that?€?s a love lost on you will be down to how accepting you can be of what is for all intents and purposes a point-and-click adventure styled after those of the early to mid nineties.'}, {'score': 91, 'text': "Honestly, if you played it and were rubbed the wrong way by the glitches, apply the patch and give it another shot. Mona may be only a campy vampire, but her heart, and the game's, are in the right place."}, {'score': 88, 'text': 'The few technical discrepancies within AVS are more than outweighed by the pile of good things there are to say about this game. A Vampyre Story is reminiscent of the glory days of LucasArts and comes equipped with an awesome amount of humour. [Issue17]'}, {'score': 80, 'text': 'It may be a bit too traditional for those raised on the episodic hand-holders of recent times, but seasoned adventurers will love the stunning visuals, smart writing, and difficult puzzles. [Jan 2009, p.119]'}]

Title: Starcraft II: Wings of Liberty
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 95, 'text': "'Quotation Forthcoming'"}, {'score': 90, 'text': "If you are into real time strategy in any form, it's hard to ignore Starcraft II. "}, {'score': 93, 'text': 'Perfectly balanced multiplayer with old school elements intact, and rich and dynamic single player campaigns. [Issue244, p.102]'}]
User Reviews Data: [{'score': 8, 'text': "The best last RTS out there. It's sad that RTS genre came to it's **** lots of fun back in 2010."}, {'score': 9, 'text': 'Its still a very good RTS! Fun and challenging gameplay especially in multiplayer. The campaign is great too. :)'}, {'score': 10, 'text': "StarCraft II: Wings of Liberty is considered by many to be the best game of all time:\nWhy StarCraft II: Wings of Liberty Is the Greatest Game of All TimeStarCraft II: Wings of Liberty stands as a masterpiece in the world of video games, combining deep strategy, compelling storytelling, and unmatched competitive gameplay. Here?€?s why it deserves the title of the greatest game of all time:Perfect Balance of Strategy and SkillWings of Liberty features three distinct factions  Terran, Zerg, and Protoss  each with unique strengths and playstyles. The game?€?s balance is legendary, requiring players to think critically, adapt quickly, and execute precise micro and macro strategies. No two games are ever the same.Epic Single-Player CampaignThe campaign offers an emotionally engaging and cinematic experience, following Jim Raynor?€?s rebellion against the corrupt Terran Dominion. The missions are varied, challenging, and full of lore, keeping players invested from beginning to end.E-Sports LegacyStarCraft II helped shape modern e-sports. It was a global phenomenon in competitive gaming, especially in South Korea, where pro players became national celebrities. The game's high skill ceiling and fast-paced gameplay made it a favorite for both players and spectators.Longevity and Community SupportReleased in 2010, Wings of Liberty still has an active player base. Blizzard continued to support the game for years with updates, expansions, and balance patches. The community contributed with custom maps, mods, and tournaments, keeping the game fresh and relevant.Technical ExcellenceWith stunning visuals (for its time), immersive sound design, and smooth online matchmaking via ****, StarCraft II set a gold standard in terms of production value. It runs well even on modest hardware, making it accessible to a wide **** conclusion, StarCraft II: Wings of Liberty isn't just a game  it's a benchmark in real-time strategy and competitive gaming history. Its combination of depth, polish, and impact on gaming culture secures its place as the greatest game of all time."}]

Title: Microsoft Flight Simulator

Title: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 100, 'text': "Although featuring the most realistic and detailed graphics, lighting and animation you've ever seen with sound effects to match, it's still the gameplay that shines the most, combining a sublime mixture of stealth and combat with the most versatile range of moves, gadgets and tactics ever to feature in a stealth game."}, {'score': 90, 'text': "Awesome in ways this space doesn't allow us to describe. [Feb 2003]"}, {'score': 90, 'text': 'But you146;ll also love Splinter Cell for being a challenge in an age when videogames have all the interaction of a fairground ride.'}]
User Reviews Data: [{'score': 10, 'text': 'The best stealth game I have ever played. It offers the player to be fully immersed in their mission with various gadgets and moves to effectively complete the challenging objectives. Splinter Cell and Prince Of Persia were Ubisoft at their absolute best. 5/5 stars.'}, {'score': 7, 'text': "the Good: the Controllers are Confortable for a Stealth game, you can move and look at the same time, you use one button to aim and another to fire, some Levels have multiple paths, you Hang automaticly if you're close to an edge especially if you fall, you Don't get paused by conversations, there's no QTEs, it's Visibility mechanic Reduce the neccesity to memorise most enemy's paths, you can jump and jump to a wall to do a highter jump, the Rifle is very accurate when you use the Scope and allows you to take out enemies, lights and cameras From safe distance, the launcher shoots non lethal ammo which is very Useful for Levels which you're not allowed to Kill, enemies have to go to the alarm to trigger it.\nthe Bad: you can only save at Specific parts and some parts you're forced to memorise them for not being able to save at any time, you always have to select the optic cable to look below door and select the lockpick to unlock doors, the pistol and rifle without Scope act like not having rifling and it's problematic on the first Levels or combat sections, some lighs cannot be destroyed even if they Don't look protected, Wall mines are very annoying to deactivate because after deactivate them on Red light it explodes forcing you to memorise the animation time and the lights of the Mine.\nthis game makes MGS2 to look like a previous Gen game for the Gameplay and controls"}, {'score': 9, 'text': "A spy stealth classic. This was the Xbox's answer to 'Metal Gear Solid 2'. With the Tom Clancy label, it plays like a real-life version of Solid Snake. At the time of release, 'Splinter Cell' was perhaps the most graphically advanced console game. Featuring realistic lighting and shadow effects, the game was a showcase of the Xbox's graphical abilities. Visually, It still holds up. The action-stealth gameplay is equally good. And while there may be too much trial-and-error, this is still a great game. I would rate it with a 9.3 out of 10"}]

Title: Ara: History Untold

[Issue404, p.118]'}, {'score': 70, 'text': "Strategy games needed new ideas, and Ara has a few of them if you're patient and play."}, {'score': 83, 'text': 'If you?€?re expecting Ara: History Untold to be a new Civilization competitor, I think you?€?re looking at it all wrong. User Reviews Data:
[{'score': 6, 'text': "It isn't that bad, but after having experienced Sid Mier's Civilization, there's no going back. Ara was bold, and I really appreciate that the copycat base design was taken into another direction, but the changed mechanics and different/new editions though unique more so dragged the game down. IMO, to me it is just a lower quality civ. I really love the art style that they adapted like Civ had for the old console games whatever it was called, but there just doesnt feel like much to do in this game vs Civ. It also seems a bit more complicated than civ as there are more resources and many many building types to shuffle, but this could very well be because Im a noob. Anyways I got bored after trying it for an hour, as again, if I play this type of game I rather just play Civ."}, {'score': 9, 'text': 'This was my first time playing a 4X turn-based game, and what a great introduction to the genre! 

Of course, this game may not appeal to every type of player due to the amount of micromanagement it requires. The graphics are decent, the sound effects are cool, and most importantly, the gameplay is satisfying in itself. 

There are a few things that need to be improved. The good news is that the game is still receiving updates and DLCs. Therefore, we can expect improvements to its UI, core mechanics, and the addition of new content, such as new maps, nation leaders, and more.

You will need patiencethis is not a 40-minute match kind of game. Build strategically, grow steadily, conquer fiercely. 

If you enjoy strategy games, resource management, crafting, and technology research, among other mechanics, you?€?ll love it. 

Give it a try.'}, {'score': 4, 'text': "4/10 because of the mid-to-end game mechanics. I wonder how this game got approved at Xbox. They didn't play it. Eventually, you reach the city cap in the early game. You cannot do much about it. There's no reason to conquer, to expand, to build, or to wage war anymore because you've reached the city cap already. Your 'empire' then stalls around the early Middle Ages. From there, you'll skip all turns until the end of the game. Also, the AI nations change their attitude for no reason, but once you are strong and advanced, you simply sign trade and/or research agreements -- and they do not matter anymore. I thought that Humankind was a low point in 4X gameplay, but I'm afraid that this game does not understand what the 4X stands for. And, oh, micromanagement hell. It gets worse the further into the future you go."}]

Title: Baldur's Gate 3
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 90, 'text': "With a vast world to explore with varied stories and secrets to discover, Baldur's Gate 3 definitely shines. The cast is largely appealing and voice acting is top notch all-around, even if the storytelling and line delivery is varied in its pace. Character progression is somewhat weak in the opening levels but has a strong foundation for a great buildcraft experience, even if it lacks some on the fly experimentation seen in Larian's past efforts. Despite some performance woes in the later parts of the game and controller hangups, this is a journey worth taking for fans of Dungeons  Dragons or those new to the role playing field."}, {'score': 100, 'text': "Larian Studios, the creators of the latest installment, have gone to great lengths to make sure they didn't disgrace any of the franchise's building blocks. The love and care is evident in Baldur's Gate 3, though needless to pretend, there aren't a few bricks crumbling here and there in this monument. It's far from a perfect title, but on the whole Baldur's Gate 3 is a brilliant computer RPG that is undoubtedly not to be overlooked. [Issue329]"}, {'score': 97, 'text': "Baldur's Gate III is an amazing game. While the length can be intimidating and the lore vast - that makes it all the more compelling and the game could easily become one of the biggest time sinks for gamers since the likes of Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim or Elden Ring released. If you're a fan of Larian Studios' previous work, DND, strategy RPGs, or any of the above, BG3 is almost certainly the game for you, and comes highly recommended."}]
User Reviews Data: [{'score': 10, 'text': 'Dieses Spiel fesselt von den ersten Minuten an. Fr??hliche und manchmal unvorhersehbare Handlung. The level design, which maximizes player freedom while maintaining a natural and cohesive progression throughout the experience, is equally remarkable.'}]

Title: GRIP: Combat Racing
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 70, 'text': 'Infernally fast vehicles racing and blowing each other up on numerous, well-designed tracks where distinction between floor and ceiling is often purely formal. If you still remember Rollcage fondly, you will probably turn a blind eye to average visuals, annoying music and some AI problems to simply enjoy the sensation of speed. [01/2019, p.79]'}, {'score': 75, 'text': 'Minor issues aside, Grip: Combat Racing is a great experience for both veterans of arcade combat racers as well as those who are willing to learn the genre. The initial learning pains and massive difficulty spikes toward the end of the game may turn away newcomers, and the catch-up mechanics and sometimes questionable physics may dissuade veteran players. For all others, though, Grip is a wild ride that offers fantastic tracks that are exhilarating to race on at lightning-fast speeds.'}, {'score': 55, 'text': 'All in all, I like GRIP more as a concept than I do in practice. Rough and tumble racing is fine, but the combat is shaky and it?€?s far too easy to accidentally clip a piece of scenery and get launched into race-losing situations. It?€?s also downright strange that a game which promotes driving like mad also requires navigating each track like I?€?m walking on eggshells. GRIP should [be] bursting free of traditional racing constraints, but instead adheres to them more often than the ceilings.'}]

A much better comparison would be one of the 3D sonic games - Grip reminds me much more of the fast sections in Sonic Heroes than anything else.

The weapons all seem to take ages to fire, I would guess about a second after pressing fire which is definitely not the case with the old futuristic racing games. Title: Bad Mojo

[{'score': 7, 'text': "Bad Mojo. **** a game I played for a bit but my pc actually stopped working, cba to buy the actual steam version, my itch download had an error or smth so I watched a full playthrough of it, short but quite the interesting **** starts off in such an intriguing way, it's a lengthy unskippable cutscene all in live action. About some guy in his apartment and his landlord interrogates him about the rent, the acting is so intriguing to watch lmao. anyway he plans to **** off but ends up stealing this amulet or something and transforms into a bug, think it was a little cockroach. anyway the gameplay is this top down exploration puzzle game using photography and images with some decent perspective work as the cockroach sprite traverses the different bits of scenary, crawling around puddles of rainwater and climbing into car engines. It's all really weird and ichy visually but it flows and plays really nicely. It's an incredibly just weird concept, probably done in film hundreds of times about morphing into a little bug, but yeah I found this super interesting and for the mid-90's very neat.7/10"}, {'score': 9, 'text': 'Bad Mojo was amazing. Title: Dragon is Dead
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 65, 'text': "This action-packed, 2D, hack-and-slash game featuring permanent death is aimed at hardcore gamers and roguelike enthusiasts who won't be put off by failure. Although the game itself is relatively short, it takes a lot of tries to reach the finale."}, {'score': 70, 'text': 'Dragon is Dead doesn?€?t exactly revolutionise the side-scrolling platformer, but between the vast skill trees, plethora of items and their effects, and different player classes, every run feels unique. Even different styles of the same character can feel like playing a completely different game, and the roguelite structure ensures players can pour countless hours into honing a playstyle they really likeor throw caution to the wind and let the RNG give them whatever it wants. A few visual bugs mar an otherwise beautiful game, and the core level design could stand to be less formulaic, but players will likely be too addicted to the gameplay loop to notice.'}, {'score': 70, 'text': 'For all the gorgeous visuals, and flashy, beautiful effects that spark and burn from abilities, there?€?s nothing offering any real bite. There?€?s no hook, and if a roguelike needs one thing, it?€?s a hook; give me an excuse to stay up until 2am figuring out new builds and synergies to slay your, admittedly, brilliant, bullet hell enemies. And so, I walked away from Dragon is Dead, which is a very odd title, by the way, feeling underwhelmed.'}, {'score': 100, 'text': 'With each death, you rise stronger. With every run, you?€?re pulled deeper. Whether it?€?s the tightly tuned combat, the rewarding progression, or the gripping narrative, this is a game that gets it. If you?€?ve been waiting for something to reignite your love for action platformers, this is your call to arms. Trust me, this Dragon is Dead is your next obsession.'}, {'score': 80, 'text': "It?€?s a gorgeous pixel-art game that liberally borrows from Diablo in all the right ways, and as a big fan of both ARPGs and roguelikes, Dragon is Dead was a refreshing mash-up of both that ends up being greater than the sum of its parts. It doesn't quite hold up into the end game, but by that point I?€?d had so much fun cosplaying as a certain Norse deity that I found it hard to complain."}, {'score': 75, 'text': 'Once I started playing Dragon is Dead, I got hooked. The game has a very satisfying gameplay loop, and it comes with an extraordinary visual style. In addition, they added a ton of loot, and you can easily swap between weapons at your own pace. The ability system is not very complex, yet it manages to deliver great depth and it?€?s just a joy to experiment with. When it comes to controls, I think it?€?s much better to play this title with a controller. That being said, even keyboard controls are fine, although the layout takes some getting used to. Games like Dragon is Dead don?€?t come by that often. This combination of platformers and roguelikes, with Diablo-like looting and inventory is rare, but it works extremely well. Granted, the game has its shortcomings, yet that didn?€?t deter me from trying out multiple runs, experimenting with loot and creating a very powerful build. It?€?s up there when it comes to great roguelikes, although it will need a tad more polishing and better music.'}]

Title: Dwarf Fortress
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 90, 'text': 'Dwarf Fortress is, initially, a little daunting. Not because it?€?s inaccessible, but because you just know that it?€?s going to turn into a real time-sink.\xa0Is it the prettiest game around? No, but it?€?s wonderfully, ridiculously deep and a sheer joy to play. If\xa0you?€?re prepared to put the time in, Dwarf Fortress will drag you into its depths and you won?€?t regret it for one second.'}, {'score': 100, 'text': 'Dwarf Fortress is a storytelling engine as much as it is a game, spitting out associations and facts and details that you can shape into a coherent and specific narrative. This is also what we do to our own lives, personifying random events so that they feel significant rather than a matter of chance. Life isn?€?t usually a satisfying narrative. It isn?€?t so much that Dwarf Fortress is a perfect simulacrum of life, but that it shines a bright light on the human tendency to look for meaning in everything. I care about my dwarves because the stories I make up about their lives are also the ones I make up about my own.'}, {'score': 91, 'text': 'A truly masterful fantasy simulation.'}]

Title: Overwatch

Title: 9 Years of Shadows
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 85, 'text': "9 Years of Shadows is an approachable pickup for anyone interested in a light and charming metroidvania. If you want some colorful and thoughtful action in your life, this one's for you."}, {'score': 65, 'text': "9 Years of Shadow is not a true metroidvania and should not be approached as such. It is a scrolling action game that is linear most of the time and does not have much content, as you can get 100 in less than ten hours. The combo system is very simple, with few moves available, and attacks from a distance are far too powerful. If you are a fan of the genre you might give it a chance, as soon as you find it in a price range you think is appropriate, but don't expect it to be your new benchmark in terms of quality."}, {'score': 80, 'text': 'Those technical troubles aside, 9 Years of Shadows is a marvelous adventure. It?€?s a more intimate take on the metroidvania formula, but what it lacks in scale it more than makes up for in clever design and synergy between its moving parts. The sheer beauty of the game and the world it asks you to explore don?€?t hurt, either. '}]
User Reviews Data:
[{'score': 8, 'text': 'Muy buen metroidvania con un progreso claro, hermosos gr??ficos y m??sica de calidad. Los enemigos normales son algo repetitivos, pero los jefes est??n bien diferenciados. Me gust?? lo de poder cambiar entre distintos elementos durante el juego para variar el sistema de combate. Historia decente, buenos personajes.'}, {'score': 7, 'text': 'Metroidvania welches gute Ans??tze hat, aber viele, welche nicht bis zu Ende gedacht sind. Ich habe zuvor das super tolle Metroidvania Prince of Persia gespielt, daher ist der Vergleich mit so einem AAA Spiel auch recht unfair/schwer. Nichtsdestotrotz konnte ich mit der Steuerung sowie mit der Geschichte bis zum Ende nicht ganz warm werden. Dazu kam, dass das Spiel an und f??r sich recht einfach ist, bis auf der Endboss. Kurz vor dem Ende wird die Steuerung bzw. das Gameplay auf links gedreht und der Endboss steht vor der T??r. Fand ich recht ungl??cklich gel??st. Insgesamt 7 von 10 Punkten. F??r geringes Geld und bei Metroidvania Lust aber trotzdem empfehlenswert.'}, {'score': 4, 'text': "I wanted so much to like this game. The art is beautiful. Game feel is great. Movement is typically pretty fast and responsive. But the more I played it. The more I just wanted it to be done.

It wants to be a metroidvania, but it just didn't quite meet the mark. Exploration is pretty fun but make sure you find everything the first time around, because looking for any missed upgrades is absolute agony.

On top of that, boss fights are frequent and uninspired. Out of the huge amount of bosses given the relatively small size of this game, I only actually enjoyed fighting 3 or 4 of them. Europa's moves etc is not nearly varied enough to keep things interesting for long. All of that is on top of the incredibly frustrating healing mechanic, and you're in for a bad time.

The last nail in the coffin is poor performance issues. It's pretty obvious certain parts of this game were not optimized. Near the end of the game, a certain boss fight becomes so choppy that it felt basically unplayable. 

I wanted to like this game, I really did. But all 9 Years of Shadows did was leave a bad taste in my mouth and the feeling that I wasted my money in the end. 

If your looking for a decent metroidvania, look elsewhere. 9 Years of Shadows certainly isn't one of them."}]

Title: Galactic Civilizations II: Twilight of the Arnor
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 100, 'text': "The technology trees alone make it impossible for someone who's sampled Twilight of the Arnor to ever go back to just playing Dark Avatar. Add to that impressive customization tools, new gameplay dynamics, better AI, graphic upgrades, new ship-builder components and completely re-done flavor text and hundreds and hundreds of smaller tweaks, fixes and changes and what you have is an absolute triumph and a new standard for turn-based-strategy games."}, {'score': 91, 'text': 'There are no two ways about it: if you like space strategy games, you have to play Galactic Civilizations II. And if you play Gal Civ II, you have to play Twilight of the Arnor.'}, {'score': 100, 'text': 'It caps the mini-trilogy with a flourish and makes us very, very eager to see what the next proper release in the franchise will have to offer.'}]
User Reviews Data:
[{'score': 9, 'text': 'Complex strategical turn based space game. Really fun, great for its time..'}, {'score': 9, 'text': "This game has some of the best A.I. you will ever find in a turn based strategy, which is a good thing since there is no multiplayer feature.  Unfortunately I feel the need to point out that if you're a fanatic TBS player like myself, it still holds no challenge (unless you let it cheat) once you figure the ins and outs of the game.  The music is average, the graphics are excellent, and the gameplay is utterly fantastic.

Galactic Civilizations 2's ship editor is one of the most impressive I have ever seen.  No need to take my word for it, just use google and look at what other people have made using it.

The planet micro management portion is quite interesting, with each planet having a chance to have certain tiles that give a  bonus to production/research/etc that makes each and every planet worth colonizing in the long run.  That crappy 4-5 quality planet that you'd normally ignore in search of something better?  It might just have a 800 production tile that makes it outstrip every other planet in the sector when it comes to building your war fleets.

Speaking of war, that's the one part of the game that keeps me from giving galactic civilizations 2 a 10 out of 10.  When it comes to combat, it really is a matter of rock/paper/scissors in terms of defense and offense.  You have lasers, missiles, guns and a corresponding defense for each.  All combat boils down to is who has more weapon 'points' that isn't covered by their enemy's defense points, and how many ships you have.  It doesn't get more complicated than that, which is a real shame.  One need only look at games like Master of Orion 2 to see how it could have been done better.  A turn based combat system that actually let you control the ships would have opened up entirely new avenues of fun and possibility.

All in all, a great game with almost no bugs (I have been playing it for well over a year and the only issue I ever encountered was a strange bug where I loaded a save and all ships had 1hp and 1 movement) that could have used minor tweaking in a few areas to truly be the game of the year instead of just great."}, {'score': 10, 'text': "Instead of spending a lot of time to say WHY this game is GREAT, I'll just make a USEFUL review.

Look that the NEGATIVE reviews (only EIGHT as of march/2014). They are of people that either:
A) say that they don't like 4x
B) say that the game is too long (do you REALLY expect to conquer a GALAXY in a couple of hours?)
C) say that the game is bad because it only supports one language: English, although the review is in English.
D) says that he likes the old games better
E) reviews Galactic Civ II badly by saying that **** is not a complete game (may be he got the game in the bundle on steam, where both games came together). Man, THIS IS NOT THE GAME YOU ARE REVIEWING.
F) give irrelevant runts and never justify his grade

So, if not even the people that gave bad grades to the game could justify those grades, I can guarantee you that the game is worthy 10x the price asked today (US 10)."}]

Title: Shadows: Heretic Kingdoms
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 70, 'text': 'Heretic Kingdoms saga returns in dignified style. Too bad that a good atmosphere, great dialogue and the alternating of action heroes is corrupted by some technical difficulties in the fight and backlogs in the optimization and user interface.'}, {'score': 70, 'text': "A game that may be too classic and entertaining, but the joy won't last for long due to its poor pacing."}, {'score': 78, 'text': "A classic RPG, well-executed, with an intense storyline and good graphics. It has some bugs, needs more variety of loot items and enemies, but it's an interesting Diablo III alternative. "}]
User Reviews Data:
[{'score': 7, 'text': "Good game with some nice ideas and a few major flaws.
In Heretic Kingdoms you take the control of the Devourer: a demon that can eat people's souls and use them as puppets. It's an ARPG in the Diablo style but, due to the Devourer's power, you'll control a variety of different characters instead of a single one. This makes the game feel fresh and interesting.
Too bad the game has some big flaws:
Loading screen are insanely long and there are quite a lot. There's a loading screen even for when you
want to change the party formation - you can have only 3 characters in your party plus the devourer - which made me almost never try new characters combination and killing one of the best characteristics of the game. You can't even equip or level up the inactive characters without traveling to the character select room (which is pointless also because it's just a room with the 'puppets' and a single vendor, there was really no need to have it), leading to a very cluttered inventory. It also kills exploration. You will really spend a insane amount of time on loading screens, and you will think twice about loading the game if you don't have a lot of free time on your hands.
Controls are bad. Really bad. They're unresponsive, the character often stops insted of attacking or just moves away, right mouse button is useless and the feeling is generally very very clunky. The combat feels often like a chore and it's not too funny.
Crafting is very tedious and pointlessly time consuming due to the badly readable interface for it. Absolutely pointless, also because you can never craft items better than what you find.

Now for the good part of it... there are some really good ideas in this. The party system is very interesting and adds something new to a overused genre. The world is beautiful and engaging, and makes you want to know more about it. The graphics are quite good: clean, readable, colorful, stylish.
The musics are absolutely fantastic. My favourite part of the game. They have a sort of arabic influence and are really, really astonishing and never bore the player.

All in all, a pretty decent game that gets pulled down by a few inexplicable flaws."}, {'score': 10, 'text': "Ok I ll start by saying this game made me create an account here to rate and review it thats how much I liked it and want to support it any way I can. I am a very hard to please gamer especially with single player games these days I think most ****.

But Heretic Kingdoms is very very good. Interesting story check. Immersive gameplay check. Cool graphicks check. New and innovative features unlike any arpg before check.
It also includes an amazing soundtrack to wrap things up and the dialogue and voice acting is immersive but also fun.

10/10 would recommend to everybody. Arpg fans and non arpg fans.

I haven't finished the game yet. I am halfway through chapter 2 but I am already looking forward to replaying it with the other characters. And I am really exited that there is book 2 and 3 coming!

Ok for negatives I can think of 1 thing that kinda bothered me that there is no respec. Not even confirmation when you pick skills to level up. But I read a dev post somewhere that respec is coming so its all good."}, {'score': None, 'text': 'Pros and Cons:
Cons: The combat is clunky.. it does not fell responsive like d3 and I mean its about the same price...
You start at lvl 19? and stats are alredy chosen for you
You fell weak right at the start of the game
The big flaw is controls are HORRIBLE!!!
Pros: I like the graphics and thats it... Go buy a real action rpg like diablo 3 they have it at 40 with the expanssion...'}]

Title: Crusader Kings III
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 90, 'text': 'Crusader Kings III has good mechanics and production but what sets it apart is the way it connects to the era it depicts. The experience leans into role-playing and personalities in a way that feels true to the image that most players have about the period between 867 to 1453. Without striving to be educational, the Paradox title also manages to be an excellent jumping-off point to learn more about the period, its main characters, its social dynamics. The development studio has also done well when it comes to post-launch support. There?€?s downloadable content, of course, but free patches have also arrived regularly, improving systems and eliminating bugs. But more work is needed both in the balance and the immersion department. Crusader Kings III is an excellent way to tell and enjoy stories and I can?€?t wait to experience how Paradox will add depth to its various mechanics.'}, {'score': 90, 'text': 'A worthy successor to Crusader Kings II. Right now, it is not as deep and demanding as its predecessor with all its expansions installed, but it still is an excellent strategy game. For newcomers it?€?s a great way to dive into the world of crowned tyrants, treacherous vassals, unfaithful wives, and inconvenient babies strangled in their cradles. [11/2020, p.56]'}, {'score': 92, 'text': 'Crusader Kings III is definitely a success. The developers made a huge self-evolving world where the players can do as they please. It?€?s unrivaled both in scale and level of detail. [Issue248, p.68] \r\n'}]

Title: FreeSpace 2
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 94, 'text': 'One of the best space sims ever made and is a solid candidate for game of the year.'}, {'score': 90, 'text': "Multiplayer of course shines, and there's never been a better excuse to splash out for that cable modem than the multi-tiered dogfights possible in FreeSpace 2. The best of its kind yet."}, {'score': 89, 'text': "Still very derivative of the games that came before it. What's different this time around is that Volition has added to the genre instead of just cloning it."}]
User Reviews Data:
[{'score': 10, 'text': 'I played this game over 20 years ago now, but still remember the story - some of the moments, especially in the later game, were that good!'}, {'score': 10, 'text': 'Two decades later and still no one has made a better space combat flight sim. Certainly there are notable attempts, but this game has stood the test of time.'}, {'score': 7, 'text': 'There are not many great and somewhat new space games out there and Freespace 2 is one of the classic great games. So every hardcore gamer should look into the game.

First of all, this game is everything else than outdated because of the Source Code Project. This mod is very easy to install and improve the game extremely, especially the graphic looks well even today. Sound and Music are also good.

So you can focus on the gameplay. The controlling of your ship is perfect: there are a lot of commands, maybe even too many. You need a joystick to enjoy it, but they are so cheap, so I bought one for 30 and get a perfect one (Thrustmasters T Flight Stick X). It takes some time to learn the many functions in the game, but it is worth it.
The problem is, the game is only about fighting in your vessel. The campaign is a series of missions, where you fight most of the time, so it is not diversified and maybe a bit outdated. I prefer the Freelancer style, where you could do much more than shooting all the time.
There is another thing I didnt like in the campaign: You are already focused on fighting and the several hotkeys, but there is so much talking during the fights, that it is almost impossible to understand them.

The story is deep, because it is based on the predecessor and the story was developed there already. So you will need some time to read the background informations. But most of the story is presented by text between the missions, so a bit boring.

--> I prefer Freelancer, because you had more freedom there.'}]

Title: Galactic Civilizations II: Dark Avatar
Critic Reviews Data: [{'score': 90, 'text': 'The inclusion of tech-prerequisites for colonization of certain environments is probably the most significant change here but there are plenty of other new features here that force the player into new and interesting situations. That you get some ample improvements in graphics and AI is just icing on the cake.'}, {'score': 100, 'text': 'Dark Avatar does much more than just add new units or new maps, it revisits the very underpinnings the game itself and adjusts them to make the whole experience richer.'}, {'score': 85, 'text': 'Part of the fun is the sheer amount of customization available.  The game can be short, long, easy or hard, or anywhere in between.'}, {'score': 100, 'text': 'A nearly flawless expansion to an already great game.'}, {'score': 95, 'text': 'This is what every expansion pack should be. Nothing seems arbitrary, and you feel like the folks at Stardock really get what 4X gamers want.'}]
